item.title: Trump Is Briefed on Options for Striking Iran as Protests Continue
item.description: The president has said he will be “hitting them very hard” if Iranian leaders kill protesters amid widespread demonstrations calling for wholesale changes in the country.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager, Eric Schmitt and Edward Wong
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Demonstrators protested in Tehran on Thursday.

item.title: Death Toll Grows as Nationwide Protests Rock Iran for a Third Night
item.description: Antigovernment unrest that began two weeks ago has intensified in recent days, as has violence.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Malachy Browne
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: UGC, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A still from video shared on social media on Friday that has been verified by The New York Times showing crowds around an open fire in Tehran, Iran’s capital.

item.title: Why Are Iranians Protesting? What to Know About the Unrest.
item.description: Demonstrations that began as outrage at the state of the economy have spread to cities across the country, amid an escalating crackdown by the authorities.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir, Leily Nikounazar and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: An image taken from a social media post on Friday shows demonstrators gathered in Tehran, Iran’s capital.

item.title: FBI’s Inquiry Into Minneapolis ICE Shooting Faces Doubts After White House’s Remarks
item.description: Ex-law enforcement officials said the administration’s declarations that the killing was justified elicited questions about the F.B.I.’s willingness to scrutinize the agent who fatally shot an unarmed activist.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush
item.media:description: Police taped off a maroon S.U.V. vehicle in which Renee Good was shot by a federal agent in south Minneapolis on Wednesday.

item.title: Anti-ICE Protests Spread Nationwide After Minneapolis Shooting
item.description: Demonstrators across the country expressed anger at the killing of a woman in Minneapolis by federal immigration agents.
item.dc:creator: Chris Hippensteel
item.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Portland, Ore., gathered along the downtown waterfront on Saturday morning.

item.title: Disinformation in Minneapolis Shooting Points at People Who Were Not Involved
item.description: Within hours of an ICE officer shooting and killing a woman, social media users misidentified the agent who fired as Steve Grove.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Salhotra and Tiffany Hsu
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Minnesota Star Tribune publisher Steve Grove in 2024.

item.title: Who Was Renee Good, the Woman Killed by an ICE Agent in Minneapolis?
item.description: Ms. Good, 37, was a poet and a mother who grew up in Colorado. Her wife said the couple had “stopped to support our neighbors” when Ms. Good was shot.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Ann Hinga Klein and Dan Simmons
item.media:description: Protests took place in cities and towns across the country following the killing of Renee Good.

item.title: U.S. Launches Major Strikes on Islamic State Targets in Syria
item.description: The airstrikes followed an even larger attack in December to avenge the killing of three Americans last year.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: A view of the Sheikh Maksoud neighborhood amid fighting in Aleppo, Syria, on Jan. 10.

item.title: Smithsonian Removes Label Noting Trump Impeachments
item.description: When the National Portrait Gallery replaced a portrait of President Trump this week, it took down a biography of his first term.
item.dc:creator: Graham Bowley, Robin Pogrebin and Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: An earlier photograph of President Trump that hung at the National Portrait Gallery included lengthy wall text.

item.title: Judge Pauses Trump Policy Ending Family Reunification for Some Migrants
item.description: The policy applied to migrants from some Central and South American countries who were awaiting visas.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella
item.media:description: Cuban migrants waited to be processed to seek asylum after crossing the border into the United States in 2023.

item.title: Venezuela’s New Leader Enlists U.S. Troops to Bring a Rogue Ship Back
item.description: Delcy Rodríguez got American help with the return of an oil tanker linked to one of her political rivals that had left the country without authorization.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Christiaan Triebert
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Delcy Rodríguez, the interim leader of Venezuela, in the country’s capital, Caracas, on Monday.

item.title: How Delcy Rodríguez, Venezuela’s Leader, Became Vital to Trump’s Plans for the Country
item.description: Delcy Rodríguez, a guerrilla’s daughter, started out as a provocateur. She pivoted to revive a ravaged economy, making her vital to U.S. plans to run Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Delcy Rodríguez, then Venezuela’s vice president, during an interview last year.

item.title: Machado Offered Trump Her Nobel, but Prize Institute Says It’s Not Allowed
item.description: After María Corina Machado, Venezuela’s opposition leader, offered her Nobel Peace Prize to President Trump, the Norwegian Nobel Institute said it cannot be “transferred to others.”
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: María Corina Machado, Venezuela’s opposition leader, offered to give her Nobel Peace Prize to President Trump, who has long coveted the award.

item.title: Bob Weir, Guitarist and Founding Member of The Grateful Dead, Dies at 78
item.description: His songwriting and rhythm guitar playing helped shape the San Francisco band’s sound as it became an American institution.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario and Mark Walker
item.media:description: Bob Weir in 1976. Over a career that spanned more than 60 years, he helped shape the sound of American rock.

item.title: Bob Weir: 10 Essential Songs
item.description: The guitarist, singer and songwriter, who died at 78, cut his own path among his elders in the Grateful Dead, and beyond.
item.dc:creator: David Browne
item.media:description: Bob Weir sang on “Truckin’,” one of the Grateful Dead’s defining tracks.

item.title: Golden Globes 2026: What to Expect From Sunday’s Awards Ceremony
item.description: Keep an eye on “One Battle After Another,” which is likely to dominate, and on the speeches. A particularly memorable one could be an Oscar lifeline.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
item.media:credit: Krista Schlueter for The New York Times
item.media:description: The scene at a preview event for the Golden Globes, being held Sunday at the Beverly Hilton in Beverly Hills.

item.title: Neon, an Indie Studio With an International Bent, Tops Globes Nominations
item.description: Neon scored more film nominations at the Golden Globes than any other studio this year with a slate of six non-English language films.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling

item.title: Trump’s Amoral World Meets Its Match in Pope Leo
item.description: The pontiff has increasingly asserted himself in the face of Trump’s aggressive words and deeds.
item.dc:creator: David Gibson

item.title: What to Know About the Vote in Myanmar
item.description: Amid a ruinous civil war, the military government is holding elections that are widely seen as a sham, as the main opposition remains barred or jailed.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Voting at a school during the first phase of the general election in Naypyidaw, Myanmar, on Dec. 28.

item.title: At the Rikers Jail, the Women Have No Library. But They Have a Book Club.
item.description: Some members of the group are awaiting trial; some are serving short sentences. In the meantime, with little else to do, they have intense discussions about literature.
item.dc:creator: Liz Krieger
item.media:credit: Anna Watts for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amanda Camia, 35, shares what she wrote in a creative writing exercise inspired by the book “Push” by Sapphire during a book club meeting.

item.title: India’s Ties With Bangladesh Fray as Elections Loom
item.description: A simmering dispute between the neighbors, who share one of the largest land borders in the world, has escalated with diplomatic protests and a sports boycott.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Saif Hasnat
item.media:credit: Sonu Mehta/Hindustan Times, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India and then Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina of Bangladesh in New Delhi in 2024. Ms. Hasina was ousted by a protest movement and fled to India, which has since been criticized by Bangladesh’s interim government and the protesters who ousted her for refusing to hand her over to face justice at home.

item.title: Will Stock Markets Sizzle Into 2026?
item.description: Returns have been fabulous but consider the potential for setbacks in this already hazardous year, our columnist says.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Sommer
